div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

THURSDAY, JUNE 6, 1907.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE'S INTERVIEW.
div.p: Egypt has always been fertile in surprises, and the latest surprise of all is the practical dementi of Mr. Dicey's interview with the Khedive. A "high palace official" has informed the representative of "Al Moayad" that Mr. Dicey's version of the interview granted to him did not accurately express the thoughts of the Khedive. He further stated that Mr. Dicey received no invitation to interview the Viceroy of Egypt, and never sent his Highness a copy of the interview before publication ; that the Khedive's views concerning the Occupation were not unknown, and had not changed; and that his views on personal rule had also undergone no modification conversation with M. René Puaux. The Nationalist Press regards this statement as an official démenti of Mr. Dicey's description of his interview with the Khedive, and we certainly think that this explanation is as likely to be correct as any other. Meanwhile Mr. Dicey, for a brief hour a favourite with the Nationalist Party, on the ground of his criticisms of Lord Cromer's administration, is now the butt of darts and arrows without number from the Nationalist archery. The "Egyptian Standard" and "AlLewa," fresh from the discovery that the Financial Adviser had been shooting pigeons at Tala, riddle the correspondent of the Daily Telegraph' with their missiles. "What" asks the "Egyptian Standard" "will the "Daily Telegraph" think of its correspondent who mistakes facts-for reasons beyond doubt foreign to his own wishes

p.hi: -and has to undergo the reprimand of an official denial."

div.p: Comment on the above is needless. We will content ourselves with the quotation "Quis tuterit Gracchos de seditione querentes?" and the English proverb-"I never swear, said the hare, its a d-d bad habit." As for Mr. Dicey and the Khedive, we do not regard the palace démenti with great interest. It is published for local consumption, the interview of which Mr. Dicey quite possibly gave an inaccurate rendering for export, and we have already commented on the difficulties of the

position of his Highness. Time and facts can | alone show us in which of the interviews, that accorded to M. Puaux or that asked for by Mr. Dicey, the Khedive's attitude towards the British occupation has been most accurately rendered, and we can afford to wait, in the meantime thanking Providence for having supplied as with a serious rival to the gigantic gooseberry and the great sea serpent,

div.head: Ivory
div.p: Nine tons of Egyptian and four tons of Abyssinian ivory have arrived in London for the quarterly sales, which commence July 23.

div.head: Egyptian Options.
div.p: Application has been made to the London Stock Exchange Committee to appoint a special settling day in Egyptian Options, Limited-Further issue of 4,500 Ordinary shares of £l each, fully paid (Nos. 20,001 to 24.500.

div.head: Inspection of Buildings
div.p: A permanent Commission has been appointed by the Alexandria Municipality to inspect the buildings of the town and report thereon. We understand that up to the present they have reported 15 houses as not satisfying the necessary requirements for safety.

div.head: Fire in Alexandria
div.p: Yesterday morning a fire broke out in a small milk-shop, in the Hamamil Street, owned by a Greek. The fire brigade arrived on the scene in a very short space of time and within an hour had completely extinguished the fire. All the contents of the shop were destroyed and the loss is estimated at £80.

div.head: Cattle Plague.
div.p: During the week ended the 3rd instant, 353 deaths from bovine typhus were reported throughout the country. Of these 80 took place in Abou Kerkas district, 3 in Minieh district, 26 in Samalout district, 34 in Beni Mazar district, 21 in Maghagha district, 31 in Fashn district, 44 in Manfalont district, 62 in Deirout district, 21 in Mallawi district, 21 in Beba district, 2 in Wasta district, 1 in Beni Souef district 3 in Fayoum district and 4 in Zagazig district.

div.head: The Collapsed Hut.
div.p: Since receiving the report which we published yesterday as we went to press, concerning the collapse of a hut in the Minet-el-Bassal quarter; we have been informed that the hut, which was built of wood, was unoccupied, and was formerly a carpenter's shop. A native woman and her two children, who were sitting against the hut were buried in the debris, and the injuries inflicted have resulted fatally to the woman and one child, while the other child is lying in hospital very seriously injured.

div.head: The Plague
div.p: For the past 24 hours the following cases of bubonic plague are reported; 3 admissions and 2 deaths in hospital at Beba ; 1 death at Assiont; 1 death at Malawi; 1 death in hospital at Deirout; 8 cases, 2 deaths outside and 1 death in hospital at Esneh; 1 recovery at Beni Souef; 1 case at Abou Tig and a recovery at Benj-Mazar. During the week ending the 3rd instant, 56 fresh cases of plagne were registered throughout the country, 25 of which occurred at Esneh ; 9 at Beni-Mazar; 4 at Assiout; 4 at Malawi; 3 at Koz; 3 at Deirout ; 3 at Fashn; 2 at Beba ; 1 at Alexandria ; 1 at Samallout and 1 at keneh.

div.head: Reuter's Egyptian Business.
div.p: Admiral Sir John W. Dalrymple Hay, presiding at the meeting of Reuter's Telegram Company, Limited, last week, said that the year which had just elapsed had been replete with events of a striking kind. Their business in Egypt was keeping pace with the political, commercial and financial developments which were taking place in that country. The services of their representative at the capital were recently laid under contribution on an occasion of great importance. He alluded to the farewell speech of Lord Cromer, the whole of which amounting to some thousands of words, was telegraphed to London. This was one of the longest messages ever received by them.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Earl of Cromer has accepted the committee's invitation to become an honorary member of the Bath Club.

During the absence of Mustapha Fehmy, Hussein Pasha Falkry, Minister of Public Works, will act as Prime Minister ; Mustapha Pasha Fehmy is leaving for Europe by the Anstrian Lloyd mail boat on Saturday.

During the absence on leave of Sir Vincent Corbertt, Mr. A. Mitchell-Innes under Secretary of State of the Ministry of Finance, who has just returned from Europe, will perform the duties of Financial Adviser to the Egyptian Government.
Crookshank Pasha and Mrs. Crookshank are leaving for England on Monday the 11th June by P. &0. India, and return to Cairo the end of October.
In Convocation at Oxford last week, the honorary degree of D.M. was conferred upon Mr. Wilfred T. Grenfell, C.M.G.,M.R.C.S., brother of Mr. Grenfell, the well-known Egyptologist
The death bas taken place at Cairo, after a short illness of Mary Augusta, only surviving daughter of Mr. Augustus de Morgan.
Mr. A. Adamson, Inspector of Irrigation, has been granted three and a half months leave of absence as from 1st August

div.head:
RAISING THE DAM.
PRESENTATION OF ANTIQUITIES.
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service.)

London, Wednesday. The Society of Antiquaries makes a generous acknowledgement in the "Times" of the money provision made and the measures taken by the Egyptian Government for preserving the antiquities whose submersion is likely to be caused by the raising of the Assouan dam. The report of Mr. Somers Clarke also appears describing the elaborate arrangements made for surveying, copying inscriptions and the sustentation of temples. The latter part of the work has been undertaken by the Department of Antiquities under the able direction of Mr. Maspero, and the remainder is to be carried out by Captain Lyons, whose case and thoroughness is acknowledged by all.

div.head:
ABYSSINIAN RAILWAYS
CONTINUATION OF WORK.
div.p: (Gazette's Special Service.)

LONDON, Thursday. It is semi-officially announced from Paris that arrangements have been made which will insure the working of that portion of the Abyssinian Railways which has been already constructed. The completion of the line as far Addis Ababa is also assured by the French Government in complete accordance with Empire Menelik.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: The Khedive has returned from Mariout to Montazah

div.head: LORD CROMER AND THE CITY.
div.p: A WELL-DESERVED HONOUR.

As announced by our London correspondent last Friday, the Court of Common Council at their meeting last Thursday, unanimously resolved to confer the freedom of the City of London upon the Earl of Cromer in recognition of his splendid services to Egypt and the Empire.

Mr. J.W. Domoney, Chairman of the City Lands Committee, in moving the resolution said, the services rendered by Lord Cromer during his twenty-five years' labours in Egypt were quite outside ordinary circumstances, and deserved the greatest recognition that could be bestowed. It was twenty-five years since Sir Evelyn Baring went to Egypt. On his arrival he found the place in a great state of chaos, when he left it its administration and policy-owing to his wise and admirable work were secure and lasting. His straightforward dealing and impartiality in all his relations with the natives accounted for his enormous influence over them.

Sir George Faudel-Phillips, in seconding the resolution, said Lord Cromer would go down to history as one of our great proconsuls, ranking with such men as Lord Clive. He was not born to greatness, but he was a man who, having great opportunities, made great epochs in our national history. There was nothing which could redound to the interest of this great Empire and add more to its reputation and glory than what had been done in Egypt. Instead of that country being, as it now is, amongst the most civilised parts of the globe, it was not too much to say that it would be in the hands of ignorant and despotic rulers, with the result that the trouble to Europe would be irreparable. Lord Cromer had won the confidence of men whose only previous experiences of government were a tradition, and knowledge of cruelty and oppression which terrified them- he had first won their confidence and then their goodwill. They were voting that day to one of their greatest living statesmen the greatest honour they possessed, and the Corporation, in so doing, was honouring a man who had done wonderful service-a service which had been recognised not only by the people of this country, but by the civilised nations of the world.

The motion was then put and carried unanimously and with acclamation, and it was referred to the City Lands Committee to make the necessary arrangements in the event of Lord Cromer's accepting the proposed compliment.
It was also resolved to confer the freedom on Lord Lister, the famous surgeon, and discoverer of the antiseptic system.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The S.S. Cyprian Prince, with passengers and general cargo left Malta on the 4th inst., and is due to arrive at Alexandria on Saturday

div.head:
EGYPT IN PARLIAMENT.
STATE RAILWAYS ROLLING STOCK.
div.p: Mr. J. M. Robertson asked Sir Edward Grey on Tuesday week whether, in view of the facts that the earnings of the Egyptian State Railways for 1905 showed an increased return per cent. on the increased capital outlay of recent years, that many of the carriages are dilapidated and insufficiently lighted, that many of the engines are from thirty to fifty-five years old, and that the tariffs for passengers and goods are higher than those of most European countries, he would advise the Egyptian Government to improve the condition of the rolling stock and at the same time to reduce passenger fares and goods rates.
Sir E. Grey : No, sir; I cannot undertake to interfere in the administration of the Egyptian State Railways. (Opposition cheers.)

div.head: RAILWAY ADVERTISING.
div.p: Mr. John Robertson also asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether he is aware that large sums of money are annually paid by the Egyptian State Railways Administration for inserting in Egyptian newspapers whole pages of their time table, although the official time table of such administration is published at regular intervals, and whether, seeing that such advertisements are greatly in excess of public requirements and are inserted in such newspapers with the object of influencing their proprietors and editors in favour of the Government policy, he will advise the Egyptian Government to discontinue the practice.
Sir E. Grey.--I am not aware of any of the facts stated or alleged in the question, and in any case I cannot undertake to interfere with the methods of making railway time-tables known in Egypt.

div.head: THE LANGUAGE QUESTION.
div.p: Mr. Robertson also asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether, seeing that Englishmen seeking to qualify by examination for posts and promotion in the Egyptian Government service were allowed to answer the questions set them in their own language, he would advise the Egyptian Government to accord to native Egyptians who present themselves at examinations for primary and secondary certificates, for diplomas granted by the higher or technical school and professional colleges, and for posts and promotion in the Egyptian Government service, the option of answering questions in their own language:

Sir E. Grey (Northumberland, Berwick). The particular changes advocated in this question are part of the general question of the encouragement of teaching in Arabic. This was dealt with recently in a speech of the Minister of Instruction, which has been presented to Parliament, and from which will be seen the extent to which the question occupies his attention. Any changes which are made must be upon the initiative of the Egyptian Government, and pending any further pronouncement by them, I can give no more information.

div.head:
EGYPTIAN GOVERNMENT.
THE COTTON INDUSTRY.
div.p: Presiding at the annual meeting of the Fine Cotton Spinners and Doublers Association, Ltd., in Manchester last week, Sir W.H. Holland, M. P., referring to the supply of cotton, said beside Sea Island cotton the Association had used a great deal of Egyptian cotton. In regard to that it was only fitting to acknowledge that the authorities in Egypt, with Lord Cromer at their head, had done their utmost to meet the wishes of the trade, and to do so in the interests of the Egyptian community by increasing the growth of Egyptian cotton. Now that Lord Cromer's successor had been appointed, he hoped they might bespeak his good offices also in that direction. They would be specially glad to see the undeveloped resources of the Sudan more largely turned to the cultivation of Egyptian cotton, for that would be a great boon to many Lancashire mills, including their own.

div.head: HOTELS IN EGYPT.
div.p: Hotels seem to be one of the best investments in this country judging by the last report of the Nungovich Hotel Company, which at the last meeting held on the 22nd May in Cairo, declared a dividend for the year at the rate of 25 per cent after placing 10% to reserve fund and granting another 10% to the Board of Directors. The Egyptian Hotels, the company that owns the well-known Ghezireh Palace and Shepheard's Hotel, gave last year a return on the paid up capital of 15 per cent and are expected to pay a similar dividend this year. The need for further hotels, especially in Cairo and Alexandria, is apparent, for during the winter season it is difficult, at times, to find accommodation for the numerous visitors arriving from Europe and America. This want is likewise shown by the number of new hotels that are in contemplation both in Cairo as well as in Alexandria, to meet the increasing demand from year to year, as mentioned in our issue of Wednesday. We are informed that a wealthy native capitalist of our city has purchased a site on the Ramleh boulevard, near the station, on which it is intended to erect a five storeyed hotel. From the photograph which has been shown to us the facade will be very handsome, and we understand that the place has been prepared by one of the leading architects in this country, the cost of the site and building being estimated at about £70,000.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in the spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limit free discussion.

div.head: CAESAR'S CAMP.
div.p: To the EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"

Sir, --Allow me to point out a blunder which Dulcamara has made in criticising the adventure of Cæsar's Camp. It is not the well-known solicitor who remains unsatisfied but it is his zealous friend. The well-known solicitor on the contrary would have enjoyed the joke had the circumstances warranted it, but the little game was played in order to come to the assistance of a suffering humanity at the Halte of Campo Cesare, and it was only the indifference of the Armenian wattman to his expostulations which exasperated him to such a point as to nearly bring him to an untimely end. Surely the growing population of Cæsar's Camp should be very grateful to the well-known solicitor.--Yours truly,
CARMENCITA.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir.- From the facts recorded by "Unsatisfied" in discussing the above subject. It is clear that. Sarah Bernhardt on this occasion did play the comedy and did so on her own account, but the friend of "Unsatisfied" did the same thing, and as we are told for the good of the public-whether he succeeded or not is not clear-but what cannot be denied is that the dormant Armenian (the sleeping beauty) enjoyed the fun immensely and it appears that the solicitor at the last moment, instead of annihilating himself, thought better to preserve his precious life in order to proclaim the rights of the people. The alternative was just as wise and it is so consoling to know that our hero did not trudge into town "A la Suffragette,"
Yours sincerely,
To the Editor of the "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir, -Since the question of the morality of the Alexandria Race Course is occupying so much of your readers attention, I feel compelled, with your kind indulgence, to endorse the remarks of your correspondents "A Race-Goer," "Sportsman" and "Diogenes". Personally, as suggested by "Sportsman," I find all my time occupied in picking out winners, which is usually more lucrative, or at any rate of more interest to me than picking on "undesirables," which apparently occupies the attention of "Paterfamilias" and an "Irate Husband." As to the "parade" of the class of women referred to by "Excluded", it seems to me that your correspondent has never visited the race course: unless I am blind ! One thing, which is to be regretted, will be the result of this correspondence, vizito draw attention to what has practically remained unnoticed, up to the present, by the majority of race goers.
Yours truly

div.head: SABA PASHA.
div.p: Referring to the retirement of Saba Pasha the "Postal Union" says :

"According to information received from Alexandria, the Director General of the Egyptian Posts, his Excellency Saba Pasha, has retired on the 1st inst. after 35 years' service. This news will be very much regretted by all who had an opportunity of appreciating this distinguished gentleman, who possessed eminent qualities of mind and heart. Saba Pasha's retirement is a great loss for the Egyptian postal service which he has organized in an excellent manner in every respect. It is also a great loss for the Postal Union, to the development of which he has much contributed by his active participation in the deliberations of the Postal Congresses of Vienna, Washington and Rome. His name will be lastingly remembered in the history of the Postal Union. We wish his Excellency Şaba Pasha a long rest in his well deserved retirement,

div.head: OBITUARY
div.p: ISMAIL NAGUIB BEY.

The impressive funeral of Ismail Naguib Bey took place yesterday morning, and was attended by many notable native and European mourners. The bereavement is particularly sad, as the deceased, who is the son of Ibrahim Naguib Pasha, Under Secretary of State, Ministry of the Interior, was not more than 23 years of age and had only recently entered upon a career, which had every prospect of proving exceptionally brilliant.

Death resulted from an accident, which occurred whilst driving in his dog-cart on Tuesday morning last. The horse, suddenly taking fright at a piece of paper lying in the roadway, became unmanageable and plunged into a tree; the shock of the collision threw the deceased from his seat and his skull was fractured from the fall. It was at first hoped that his life might be saved, but, in spite of every endeavour that medical and surgical aid could devise, the attempt proved fruitless and the patient succumbed to his injuries towards the evening of the same day,

div.head: COMMISSION MUNICIPALE.
div.p: La Commission Municipale s'est réunie hier soir à 4 h. 1/2 p.m. sous la présidence du Dr. Schiess Pacha. 16 membres étaient présents.
RÈGLEMENT SUR LES CONSTRUCTIONS.
Après une longue discussion sur les maisons récemment écroulées, la Commission a décidé d'appliquer aux constructions le règlement provisoire suivant : Projet de Règlement Concernant les

p.hi: Constructions. Le Président de la Commission Municipale,

div.p: Vo l'art. 15 para. 8 décret du 5 Janvier 1890 instituant la Commission Municipale d'Alexandrie.
Vu la délibération de cette Commission en date du......... approuvée par S.E. le Ministre de l'Intérieur en date du......... arrête :.

Art. 1. Les mesures et propositions suivantes seront appliquées à titre transitoire en attendant la promulgation d'un règlement définitif concernant les routes ainsi que le contrôle des constructions dans la ville d'Alexandrie.
"Aucune construction ne pourra être élevée " dans le périmètre de la ville d'Alexandrie "avant que les plans de la bâtisse ne soient " soumis à la Municipalité et approuvées " par elle.

Les dessins à présenter par les intéressés " devront comprendre, 1° les plans du rez de " chaussée et des divers étages avec élévation " et coupe à l'échelle de 1/100, 2° un plan " d'ensemble de l'emplacement à construire, " des voies qui le bordent on l'a voisinent ainsi " que des dispositions de drainage, à l'échelle - de 1/1000."
"L'Administration devra, dans le délai de " quinze jours à partir de la présentation des " dessins ci-dessus, manifester son approbation

et délivrer en-conséquence la rokhsa de " construction. Au cas où ces dessins n'auraient " pas été agréés, la Municipalité devra dans le même délai en taire part aux intéressés et " leur communiquer les observations qu'elle "croira devoir formuler. L " Aucune modification au plan approuvé " par la Municipalité ne pourra être apportée " sans l'agrément écrit de cette dernière.
"Les agents préposés à la surveillance des

constructions constateront toute inobservation des plans approuvés et dresseront les " procès-verbaux y relatifs dans les formes et " avec les mêmes sanctions adoptées en " matière de contravention au règlement du " Tanzim ;
Art.2 --Le présent arrêté entrera en vigueur, " 30 jours après sa publication au journal officiel
Fait à Alexandrie, le...

M Foster ayant fait remarquer qu'il existait dans ce règlement certaines lacunes, les membres se sont unanimement ralliés à sa proposition d'y ajouter des clauses précises concernant la qualité et la résistance des matériaux, ainsi que le droit pour la Municipalité de suspendre le travail en cas de non-observation du cahier des charges.
DEMANDES DE CRÉDITS Les demandes de crédits suivants, sauf celui de l'Abattoir, ont été votées sans discussion.
A prélever sur le budget extraordinaire :
a) L.E. 15,000, pour la commande de dalles et la continuation des travaux de confection des routes.
b) L.E. 200, pour l'impression en arabe du recueil des règlements intéressant la Municipalité et de celui des contrats passés avec les diverses Sociétés.
c) L.E. 350, pour achats de nouveaux instruments pour le Service Technique.
d) LE, 3,300, pour achat divers et aménagements à l'Abattoir.
e) L.E. 1,125, pour construction de nouveaux chalets de nécessité dans divers quartiers.
f) L.E. 340, pour l'aménagement d'allées et routes, et autres travaux au jardin Nouzha.
A prélever sur la réserve du budget ordinaire :
g) L.E. 400, à titre supplémentaire pour la vaccination

AU SUJET DE L'ABATTOIR Au sujet de l'Abattoir M. Kingham a réclamé, avant d'approuver le crédit, un état des dépenses et des recettes de cet établissement pour voir s'il rend quelque chose. Il y a longtemps, d'ailleurs, que M. Kingham demande en vain cet état. Une discussion s'étant engagée à ce sujet, l'ajournement de la question proposé par quelques membres, a été repoussé et l'Administration devra présenter l'état demandé.

Les Maisons ÉCONOMIQUES En l'absence de M. Rieti, c'est M. Fenderl qui a pris la parole en faveur des maisons économiques. Il a demandé en conclusion que la Municipalité renonce dès à présent à la moitié lui revenant sur le prix du terrain, qu'elle se charge de la confection des rues séparant les blocs et qu'elle exempte des impôts pendant 5 ans aux mêmes conditions qu'elle a imposée aux acquéreurs des terrains des quais. Une longue discussion s'est engagée à ce sujet, qui s'est terminée par le vote de la proposition Padoa Bey : "la Commission vote en principe de prendre consignation du terrain." Quand le comité aura précisé ses conditions, a expliqué Padoa Bey, les conseillers décideront sur l'ensemble en connaissance de cause.
ELARGISSEMENT DE LA ROUTE DE RAMLEH

En l'absence de M. Salvago, M. Kingham a proposé l'élargissement de la route de Ramleh jusqu'à la Ibrahimieh, Malgré les protestations de M. l'administrateur sur les difficultés de l'exécution immédiate, la proposition de M. Kingham a été votée, à savoir : l'élargissement de la route et l'invitation aux services de présenter leur rapport avant le 1er octobre prochain." Au cours de la discussion, très intéressante intervention de M. Barbazza, pour réclamer un emplacement réservé aux piétons sur la diet route, les trottoirs étant envahis par les cavaliers. La même observation pourrait être faite pour les trottoirs du quai ou des bicyclistes se lancent à toute vitesse au milieu des promeneurs. INTERPELLATION SUR LA COMPAGNIE DES EAUX M. Fenderl a développé une interpellation sur la nouvelle émission d'actions de la Compagnie des Eaux d'Alexandrie. La Municipalité, ayant droit à la moitié des bénéfices restants après la distribution d'un dividende de 10% aux actionnaires, se trouve lésée par l'augmentation incessante du capital qui atteindra avec l'émission en perspective 600.000 livres. M. Kingham a proposé de renvoyer la question au Comité du Contentieux pour savoir si le Municipalité a le droit de s'immiscer dans cette affaire; il n'est pas douteux, en effet, que la Municipalité soit lésée par ladite émission, puisque la Compagnie pourrait se. procurer les sommes dont elle a besoin de façon beaucoup plus avantageuse, soit par exemple par l'émission d'obligations à 4%.--M. Padoa Bey a répondu que le noeud de la question réside dans l'intention de la Compagnie: si celle-ci est de bonne foi, il n'y a pas lieu d'intervenir, à son avis; si au contraire, son intention a été dolosive, la Municipalité peut intervenir: La discussion s'est arrêtée là et a été renvoyée à une séance ultérieure, ainsi que l'interpellation de M. Fenderl sur le projet de route de la corniche. AUTRES DÉCISIONS Comme membres du Comité d'examen pour le concours aux postes nouvellement créés ad service sanitaire, la Commission a nommé: MM. Padoa Bey, Dr. Valensin, et Mahfouz Bey. En ce qui concerne la concession d'une jetée. promenade au Port-Est, M. Pados Bey a proposé de convoquer M. Joseph à la prochaine séance pour exposer ses conditions ; ce qui & été accepté. Le projet de règlement pour le stationnement des barques dans le canal Mahmoudieh a été voté avec faculté pour la Municipalité de fixer le tarif. Ont été nommés comme membres provisoires à la Délégation, en remplacement de M.M. Ralli, Dr. Valensin, Mansour Bey et Yehia Pacha qui partent pour l'Europe, M.M. Mahfouz Bey, Ehrlich, Tambacopoulo et Barbazza.

div.head: CASINO SAN STEFANO.
div.p: Nous rappelons que c'est ce soir à 9 h. 1/2, qu'a lieu au Casino le 2me concert Serato. L'accueil trouvé jusqu'ici auprès des dilettanti Alexandrins par le célèbre violoniste dans ses précédents concerts, nous fait présager pour ce soir encore un immense succès.
Prix d'entrée 20 P.T.

Dimanche prochain 9 courant à 10 h. 1/2 da matin, ouverture des grands concerts classiques par un festival Wagner. Le programme uniquement composé des oeuvres du Maître, choisies parmi les meilleures nous promet un vrai régal artistique: y figurent la Marche Funèbre de Siegfried du Crépuscule des Dieux et l'ouverture Ein Faust, qu'il nous sera donné d'entendre pour la première fois à Alexandrie..

div.head: MOTOR-CAR ACCIDENT.
div.p: A motor car accident, of which the results might easily have proved more disastrous, occurred on the Pyramid road on Tuesday at midday. Ali Fouad Bey, son of the Minister of Justice, accompanied by a lady and two gentlemen, in his endeavour to avoid a collision with a flock of sheep, drove his car into a tree on the roadside. All the occupants of the automobile were violently thrown from the car and an Arab, while trying to herd the sheep, was severely injured in the ribs. For tunately, no one else was hurt, and, beyond experiencing a serious fright, the motorists had miraculous escape. The injured man has been taken to Kasr el-Aini Hospital,

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie). Le marché a été faible et sans affaires durant toute la matinée; vers la fin, toutefois, la cote s'est légèrement raffermie sur le bruit, non confirmé d'ailleurs, que le syndicat aurait čommencé ses opérations. .
Les fluctuations n'ont pas eu d'importance : l'Agricole est un peu mieux à 8 3/8 vendeurs, tandis que la National Bank recule encore à 22 3/8.
En baisse notable les Eaux du Caire s'inscrivent à 114 les actions et 205 les parts de jouissance:

Plus faibles aussi les Markets à 24, la Cassa di Sconto à 161 l'ancienne et 160 la nouvelle, la Banque d'Athènes à 125 1:2, la Delta Land à 2 3/16;l'Urbaine à 5 1/16, la Banque d'Orient à 122 1/2, l'United à 9/16- acheteurs, et la Tariffs à 3 3/4.
L'obligation Crédit Foncier est, en revanche, plus fermé & 322 l'ancienne et 268 1/2 la nouvelle: la Building Lands reprend à 3 1/16.
Impossible de prévoir la tendance du marché pour le moment. Il semble pourtant que pour certaines valeurs, nous ne sommes pas loin des plus bas cours.

En dernière heure nous apprenons que dans la séance qu'il a tenue hier soir, le syndicat ou consortium a fixé les valeurs qu'il achèterait ainsi que leur prix d'achat; mais il ne nous a pas été possible de savoir s'il avait effectivement commencé ses opérations ce matin.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA BONDED WAREHOUSE
div.p: COMPANY. LTD.

L'Assemblée Générale Extraordinaire présidée par M. J. de Menasce vient de donner pouvoir au Conseil d'Administration de procéder au changement de la dénomination actuelle en une dénomination nouvelle ainsi conçue "Egyptian Bonded Warehouse, Cy. Ltd." (ex-Alexandria.)

div.head: CINEMATOGRAPHE URBANORA
div.p: De l'avis unanime, le nouvel Urbanora est superbe et tous lui prédisent le plus grand succès. Il est juste de dire que tout ce que l'on peut demander à un Cinématographe pour en faire un modèle se trouve réuni dans cet Établissement: Situation centrale et exceptionnelle, salle splendide et bien disposée, permettant de voir de toutes places, création unique en Egypte, entrées complètement indépendantes pour chaque classe, nombreuses sorties de secours, garantissant contre toute éventualité, etc. Quant aux programmes, nous disons seulement qu'ils sont inédits, et qu'ils contiennent des attractions pour les entr'actes comme seul l'Urbanora 'est à même d'en présenter.

En un mot la faveur que le publie marque pour cet Établissement est vraiment bien méritée et le monde élégant, le High-Life 'Alexandrin, qui en forme la clientèle assidue, continuera toujours à se rendre au premier Cinématographe d'Alexandrie où il est certain de passer la meilleure des soirées en applaudissant un spectacle de premier ordre, exclusivement réservé aux familles.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES

Le Caire, Mercredi 5 Juin 1907. Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres a haussé hier de 1/8 à 3 5/8 pour cent.Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais a baissé de 1/8 à 84. L'Unifiée est remontée de 1/4 à 100 1/4. La National Bank a également regagné 1/4 à 23. L'Agricole a, par contre, perdu 1/8 à 8 1/2, de même que la Delta Light à 9 7,8. La Daïra Sanieh a avancé de 1/8 à 15 1/8.
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Égyptien a haussé de 7 francs à 712. La Banque d'Athènes est restée avariée à 128.

Ici, la séance de ce matin a été encore mauvaise, en ce sens du moins que les offres ont continué à prédominer, qu'elles ont trouvé difficilement des contreparties et que les cours. ont été cassés avec quelques rares transactions sans importance. Certes, la situation ne présente aucun caractère inquiétant ; elle est même naturelle en cette période de l'année, qui marque d'ordinaire le début de la saison morte. Mais on tient compte du fait qu'un Syndicat s'est formé avec mission de relever les prix exceptionnellement bas des bonnes valeurs, et on se plaint amèrement que ce consortium ne donne même pas signe de vie pour enrayer une dépression dont la persis: tance pourrait finir par déterminer les effets lamentables que la formation du Syndicat était justement appelée à prévenir ou tout au moins à atténuer. On en conclut, naturellement, que ce n'était pas la peine de fonder un Syndicat pour lui permettre de tirer parti de la débâcle alors qu'elle se serait pleinement produite.

Hâtons-nous de le dire, ce sont là des appréciations qui nous paraissent passablement injustes., Le Syndicat vient à peine de naître; il faut lui laisser le temps d'étudier la situation afin d'agir à bon escient. Il a, d'ailleurs, promis, officiellement, de commencer ses opérations dans le courant de cette semaine, dont nous ne sommes pas tout à fait à la fin. Au demeurant, il ne faut pas perdre de vue que le Syndicat a attendu patiemment jusqu'à avant hier que les cours forcés établis le 22 Avril dernier fussent abolis au Caire, en d'autres termes que la côte fût rendue entièrement libre. Il serait done abusait de se refuser à accorder au consortium un délai de moins de trois jours pour lui permettre d'entrer sage. ment et sérieusement en activité. En attendant, la National Bank a reculé à 22 9/16. L'Agricole a faibli à 8 5/16-3/8, la Banque d'Athènes à 126, la Banque d'Orient à 122 et la Cassa di Sconto à 163. Le Crédit Foncier a été mieux tenu à 710 ; l'obligation à lots ancienne est revenue à 821 La Behera a rétrogradé à 29-30. l'Immobilière à 378, l'Enterprise and Development à 10-10 1/4 et les Allotments à 2 3.16. Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire sont tombées à 205. Les actions privilégiées Tramways d'Alexandrie ont été cotées 164 ex-coupon et les dividendes 316, ex-coupon également. Dans le groupe des valeurs hôtelières, les Egyptian ont fléchi à 6 11/16. Les National sont remontés à 2 13/16. Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land a été ramenée à 2 3,16; les Estates à 11/4 et les Constructions à 0 9/16-5/8. Les Salt and Soda ont avancé à 19 sh. 9-20. Les New Egyptian se sont raffermis à 17 sh. 6. 1 Le bruit a de nouveau couru hier à la Bourse d'Alexandrie que les négociations concernant le projet de fusion entre la Salt and Soda Ltd. et la Port-Saïd Salt Association seraient sar le point d'aboutir. Sur cette rumeur, les actions de la Port Said Salt Association ont haussé aux abords de 17 shellings. L'assemblée générale ordinaire de la Société de Travaux Publics au Caire, qui s'est tenue le 28 Mai dernier à Bruxelles, a approuvé les comptes de l'exercice clos le 15 Février 1907. | Les bénéfices nets sur entreprises et réalisations de terrains et de titres du portefeuille se sont élevés à Frs. 437,953.16. L'assemblée a décidé de répartir ce bénéfice, conformément à l'article 36 des Statuts, de la manière suivante lo. Au fonds de réserve 5% ; 20. dividende de 5% par an sur le montant libéré des actions privilégiées (soit pendant 16 mois et 3 jours sur le montant total) ou Frs. 33.54 par titre; 30. dividende de 5% par an sur le montant libéré des actions ordinaires, soit, comme ci dessus, Frs. 33 54 par titre. Une somme de Frs. 13,575.51 a été reportée à nouveau. Ces dividendes sont payables le 15 Juin courant. Les recettes de la Delta Light Railways Co. pour la semaine au 25 Mai dernier ont été de L.E. 4,494 contre 3,592 en 1906, soit en aug. mentation de L.E. 902. Les recettes totales depuis le 1er Avril 1907 ont atteint L. E. 37,788 contre 29,890 pour l'exercice précédent, soit en plus-value de L.E. 7,898. . - Les recettes des Egyptian Markets Ltd. I pour la semaine au 25 du mois dernier se sont élevées à LE 740 contre 636 en 1906, soit en augmentation de L.E. 104. Les recettes totales depuis le 1er Janvier 1907 se chiffrent par L.E: 17,044 contre 14,400 pour l'exercice précédent, soit en plus-value de LE. 2,644. - Les recettes des Tramways d'Alexandrie pour la semaine au 1er Juin courant ont été de LE. 1,955 contre 1,568 en 1906, soit en augmentation de LE. 387. Les recettes totales depuis le ler Janvier 1907 ont atteint L. E. 37,144 contre 29,839 pour l'exercice précédent, soit en plus-value de L.E. 7305.

div.head: AUFGEBOT.
div.p: Es wird hiermit bekannt gemacht, dass der bayerische Staats Angehörige Hermann Paulus seines Standes Kaufmann geboren in München 32 Jahre alt, wohnhaft in Alexandrien Sohn des in München verstorbenen Kaufmanns Josef Paulus und dessen in München wohnhaften 72 Jahre alten Ehefrau Elise geborenen Zehetner

und die österreichische Staatsangehörige Emilie Wrba geboren in München, 26 Jahre alt. wohnhaft in München Tochter des in München wohnhaften 67 Jahre alten Schmiede-Meisters Georg Wrba und dessen in München wohnhaften 58 Jahre alten Ehefrau Anna geborenen Wurm beabsichtigen sich mit einander zu verehelichen und diese Ehe in Gemäßheit des Reichsgesetzes vom 4. Mai 1870 vor dem unterzeichneten Beamten abzuschließen. Alexandrien, den 1 Juni 1907.
gez. WUNDERLICH.

div.head: SENSATION IN GERMANY. IMPORTANT RESIGNATIONS. INFLUENCING THE EMPEROR.

div.p: A sensation has been caused by the resignation of Prince Eulenburg, an influential Court personage, Count Hohenau, the Emperor's aide-de-camp, and Count Kuno Molthe, commander of the city garrison. These resignations are the result of press revelations that they belonged to a clique unduly influencing the Emperor in obtaining positions for their friends.
(Reuter)

div.head: THE CHINESE RISING. A MISSIONARY STABBED.

div.p: The "Daily Mail" learns from Hong-Kong that the missionary, Mr. Pollard, at Chu-tung fu has been stabbed in the lungs and mercilessly beaten by Chinese.
(Reuter)
A disturbance has taken place at Wei-chow in the Tung-Kung district. A mob is attacking the city. Troops are being despatched from Canton.
(Reuter)

div.head: ABYSSINIA RAILWAY COMPANY. ADDIS ABABA EXTENSION.

div.p: It is semi-officially stated that all arrangements have been made to ensure the working of the Abyssinian railway extension to Addis Ababa. The French Government and Menelik are entirely in accord on the subject.
(Reuter)

div.head: HOUSE OF LORDS. IRISH AGRARIAN OUTRAGES.

div.p: A prolonged debate took place on the agrarian outrages in Ireland. Lord Denman, on behalf of the Government, admitted that considerable agrarian disturbance existed in certain districts which was causing great anxiety. The Government deplored this agitation and had no option but to administer the law with firmness and decision.
(Reuter)
A sailing vessel, cargoed with contraband ammunition for Tripoli, has been blown up off Zarvis. It is said that fifty persons have perished
(Havas)
The newspapers say that King Edward and M. Fallières will visit King Haakon together this summer.
(Havas)
The inscrits maritimes of Marseilles and St. Nazaire have decided to resume work.
(Havas)
The seamen are hopelessly divided: many are resuming work.
(Reuter)
The seamen are hopelessly divided: many are resuming work.
(Reuter)
M. Paplan, ex-Assistant Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, has been condemned to three months' imprisonment for the illegal communication of documents to the deputies.
(Havas)

One of the Tsar's daughters has contracted diphtheria: the Tsarina is personally nursing her.
(Reuter)
Eight political prisoners have been sentenced to death for participating in the mutiny of 14th April.
(Reuter)

According to a telegram received from Teheran a force of Persian cossacks, with cavalry, infantry, and mountain guns, have left for Kermanshah against Salar-el-Dowleh. There have already been many casualties on both sides.
(Reuter)
A slight earthquake shock was felt yesterday, No damage has been done.
(Reuter)

The following matches have been abandoned: Yorkshire v. Kent. Cambridge University v. South Africans, Middlesex y Essex. Notts beat Sussex by 6 wickets. Surrey beat Leicestershire by 45 runs. Lancashire beat Somerset by 2 wickets. Warwickshire beat Northamptonshire by 125 runs at Birmingham.
(Reuter)
Derby. 1. Orby; 2. Wool Winder ; 3. Slieve Gallion. Won by two lengths : half a length dividing second and third. Time 2 minutes and 44 seconds.
(Reuter)

Some interesting details are given in the current issue of "Fry's Magazine," in the course of an article on the 127 races for the Derby which have been run since it was started in 1780. If we admit that all Derby horses are good, the writer says, with the reservation that some are very much better than others, think of all the fine horseflesh that is comprised in 2,124 horses, which is the number that have so far run in the historic race. The largest number that have ever started in one race was thirty-four, in 1862, when Caractacus turned out to be the winner. Going to the other extreme, there were only four starters in 1794, when Dedalus won. Small fields were commoner in the early years of the race than they were at any time afterwards, until we come to quite the most modern era, seven fields of less than ten runners each having been sent to the post since Ormonde's year in 1886. The greatest number of subscribers to the race was in 1900 (Diamond Jubilee's great year), when there were 301.

In regard to the jockeys, the record for wins "is held by Robinson, deceased, away back in the early part of last century, when he won the race six times-four times in five years. The famous Fred Archer, Clift, Buckle, and J. Arull won five times; S. Arnull (the first winner), W. Scott, and J. Watts four times; while many other jockeys have two and three successes to their credit. It is a fine thing for a jockey to win the Derby-in cash as well as in glory. Often enough it is worth at least a thousand pounds to him; and it is said that had Alfred Day, who had the mount on Kingstown, only beaten Wild Dayrell, in 1855, he would have had the whole of the stakes, amounting to £6,000, for his trouble. Probably the jockeys did not get very much in the early days of the Derby, and it is even said that Custance only received £100 for winning on Thormanby in 1860."

div.head: MONEY AND SHARE MARKET.
div.p: The Money Market.

In financial circles there was a slight flutter at the settlement this week, but in the end there was more than enough money to go round. There seems no probability that the Bank of France will reduce its rate, and so long as our powerful neighbour feels it necessary to strengthen its poßition, it is not probable that the Bank of England will make a move downward. At the same time, we confirm what we wrote last week, that there is no reason to look for any pressure until the early months of the Autumn, and no one feels inclined to predict the result of the Autumn demand. To be well aware of a possible stringency is the best way to avoid it and the conservative policy is likely to be followed by our banks and financial institutions.
For the moment the price of gold is down, the quotation being 77/107 per ounce. Silver also has receded a fraction to 31. In neither case, however, is the reduction likely to be permanent.

With the return of currency from the provinces, the stock of coin and bullion at the Bank shows a rise of £95,000, notwithstanding the efflux of over £500,000 for abroad. The active note circulation has contracted by £89,000, and the result is an addition of £184,000 to the reserve, which now stands at £24,864,000. The proportion of reserve to liabilities is practically unchanged at 461 per cent. Last year the total reserve amounted to £23,177,000, and the proportion was about 44 per cent.

The past week has not been without its financial discomforts, and there seems no doubt that the steady shrinkage in the value of "stocks and shares which has been going on for some time past has been undermining the resources of a great many old Stock Exchange houses. At the same time, the few failures that have occurred from time to time are for very small amounts, and there is no speculation the result of which can bring about any serious trouble. Heavy expenses and want of business, leading to yearly losses, are the main causes of complaint, and these readily lend themselves to treatment as things get better, as they must do.

It is satisfactory to note that during the latter part of the week the tone of the stock markets has been much firmer. Two failures have been announced, Messrs. Hubert Brunton & Co., and Messrs. James Shepherd & Co., both highly respectable firms, but the amounts for which they have failed are comparatively small.
To-day the tone has not been quite so favourable, owing to the small amount of business transacted.

After continuing in a very depressed state for some weeks, the gilt-edged market on Wednesday developed a very cheerful tone. Consols which had been put down to 843, closed for higher. Yesterday the improvement was maintained, and Consols registered a further advance of t for cash and account. This morning the premier security eased off slightly on a few sales to close accounts. The closing price to-night for cash is 84 9/16, a loss on the day of . For the account yesterday's quotation, 84 13/16, is unchanged.
The foreign section is quiet and steady. There has been some revival of interest in Russians, and the Fives have been up to 839, but have receded to-day. The Fours leave off at 75.
Japanese are firm, but little business has been done in them. The changes in prices are insignificant, and are confined to about two of the stocks..

In sympathy with the gilt-edged market, home railway shares have been much steadier, although there is still a certain amount of liquidation, which helps to keep prices low. In most cases, however, a fairly appreciable advance is shown, Brighton Deferred have Auctuated somewhat. On Wednesday the shares were put up 1%, but yesterday gave way ) to 864. South Western Ordinary and Deferred and South Eastern were marked up a full point yesterday,
To-day there has been a slight reaction in several cases. Brighton and Deferred' have dropped , and Districts have had a sharp fall of 2 to 101.

The American market has now a better apI pearance, but the revival was hindered yesterday by the Decoration Day holiday in New York. The previous day the market had been very firm, and substantial advances were registered in most of the leading shares. Yesterday Unions were quoted ex dividend and rights, together nearly 3 dollars, and at the close were about 2g up, a gain for the two days of about 5, Southern Pacifics rose 1}, and Chesapeake 24.
Americans have to-day been quiet, but the movements are generally in favour of holders.

There has not been much business passing in the Egyptian market during the past week, and prices are practically unchanged. National Bank of Egypt have been as good as 23, but closed off again yesterday at 221. To-day they have been very firm, and leave off at 23. Although there has been further good buying for investment of Agricultural Bank of Egypt, the price, after being 8, closed last night with Egypt sellers at 84. They leave of to-night at

A large business has been done in Egyptian Markets at the advanced prices of 26/-8. and 26/3, and five or six thousand shares have changed hands at these figures. Egyptian Estates have been dull but close better at 1 5/16--7/16. The Deferred are unmentioned. Delta Preference Bearer are firmer with buyers at 97-104, and the Debentures are quoted 98-100. Delta Land and Investment are steady at 21-).

Daira are a quiet market at 143-15), and the Deferred 78-80. Salt and Soda are about | 19/-. and Union Fonciere 54. Comptoir Financier are flat without support at 39-4. Land and General Trust at $ are steady, and Khedivial Mail Ordinary at 17, Bank of Roumania have been dealt in at 9.

This market has shown some signs of a revival, but the upward movement has received a set-back as the result of liquidation in connection with some weak accounts Yesterday the tone was distinctly more cheerful in the early hours, but fell away later, and the leading shares closed with slight declines.
Mining shares have not moved much to-day, and the tendency has been rather adverse.
Egyptian mining shares are still neglected, and the changes in prices are quite fractional. Egyptian Mines Exploration leave off rather better at 2/-. Nile Valley close at 1/-.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
div.p: KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT
Liverpool, May 30th. Egyptian Cotton on the Spot continues to be neglected, the amount of actual business since the holidays being small,
The quotations of Brown are reduced 1/16d. per lb., and Uppers 1 8d. per lb. .
A fair speculative business has been done in Futures, and the following are the latest quotations:

American Futures. Since our last report on the 16th instant, there has been considerable interruption to business in consequence of the variove Whitsuntide Holidays. In the earlier period under review, the market, although generally tending higher, was extremely sensitive, and experienced several sharp reactions, but since yesterday afternoon upon very unfavorable weather conditions reported from Texas, Louisiana, and the Mississippi district, an enormous business has been transacted at materially advanced prices, to-day's closing values being 45% to 48 points higher for Old Crop, and 50 to 52) points higher for the New Crop positions than those of Thursday the 16th instant.

Extensive Bull purchases, heavy covering by Bears, and the New York market being closed to-day, have produced an extraordinary position. It is quite impossible to forecast the immediate future, but after all, it is still only the end of May and with New Crop positions at practically 64d per lb, one would suppose that mostly everything unfavorable has been fairly well discounted.
The latest quotations are, delivery :-

div.head: Credit Franco-Egyptien.
div.p: SOCIÉTÉ ANONYME AU CAPITAL DE 12.500,000 FRANCS
Assemblee. Generale Annuelle.
MM, les Actionnaires sont convoqués en Assemblée Générale Ordinaire pour le Vendredi 14 Juin 1907 à trois heures et demie de relevée, à la salle des Ingénieurs Civils, 19 Rue Blanche à Paris.
ORDRE DU JOUR Examen et approbation des comptes de l'exercice clos le 31 Mars 1907.
Fixation du Dividende.
Nomination des Commissaires pour l'exercice 1907-1908.
Autorisations diverses.

Pour faire partie de l'Assemblée, il faut être propriétaire d'au moins 20 actions, les porteurs d'un nombre inférieur pourront toutefois se réunir pour atteindre ce chiffre et se faire représenter par l'un d'eux.
Pour assister à l'Assemblée, MM, les Actionnaires devront déposer leurs actions :
A Paris : au plus tard le 11 Juin 1907. 1o.--Au Siège Social, 3 Rue Saint-Georges.
20.--Au Crédit Mobilier Français, 3 & 5 Rue Saint-Georges et aux Caisses de tous les Établissements de Crédit de Paris et de leurs succursales.
En Egypte : au plus tard le 31 Mai 1907. lo.--Au Siège de la Direction à Alexandrie.
20,- Aux caisses du Crédit Lyonnais, du Comptoir National d'Escompte, de l'Anglo Egyptian Bank, de la Banque Impériale Ottomane et de la Deutsche Orient Bank.

Les récépissés de dépôt effectués en d'autres lieux qu'au Siège Social à Paris et au siège de la Direction à Alexandrie devront parvenir au Siège social ou au siège de la Direction dans les délais respectifs plus haut indiqués du 11 Juin 1907 et du 31 Mai 1907 : ces récépissés devront mentionner les numéros des actions déposées.
Les pouvoirs des Actionnaires qui useront de la faculté de groupement devront être remis dans les mêmes délais.

L'Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat informe le Public qu'un examen aura lieu le 12 Juin prochain et les jours suivant s'il y a lieu à 10 heures du matin, au Service Central de la Voie, pour deux emplois d'Agents des Domaines, au Bureau de l'Ingénieur Divisionnaire de la Voie et des Travaux, à Assiout (Haute-Egypte).
La paie de début sera de L'Eg. 8 par mois.

Les candidats, qui doivent être de nationalité égyptienne et possesseurs, au moins, du certificat d'études primaires, devront présenter leurs demande et titres à Mr. l'Ingénieur en Chef de la Voie et des Travaux, au Caire, avant le 9 Juin 1907.
La priorité sera donnée aux candidats possédant le diplôme de sortie de l'Ecole des Arts et Métiers et à ceux connaissant une langue étrangère (anglais on français).
Le Caire, le 31 Mars 1907. 30405-2-2
